etymologies: Old English, originally a variant of of (which combined the senses of ‘of’ and ‘off’)

notes.text: Off of is often used in place of the preposition off in contexts such as she picked it up off of the floor (compared with she picked it up off the floor). Although off of is recorded from the 16th century (it was used by Shakespeare) and is logically parallel to the standard out of, it is regarded as incorrect in standard modern English

definitions: away from the place in question; to or at a distance

examples.text: the man ran off
she dashed off to her room
we must be off now

definitions: away from the main route

examples.text: turning off for Ripon

definitions: so as to be removed or separated

examples.text: he whipped off his coat
a section of the runway had been cordoned off

shortDefinitions: so as to be removed or separated

definitions: absent; away from work

examples.text: take a day off
he is off on sick leave

definitions: starting a journey or race; leaving

examples.text: the gunmen made off on foot
they're off!

definitions: so as to bring to an end or be discontinued

examples.text: the Christmas party rounded off a hugely successful year
she broke off her reading to look at her husband

shortDefinitions: so as to bring to end

definitions: canceled

examples.text: tell them the wedding's off

definitions: (of a menu item) temporarily unavailable

examples.text: strawberries are off

definitions: (of an electrical appliance or power supply) not functioning or so as to cease to function

examples.text: switch the TV off
the electricity was off for four days

shortDefinitions: (of electrical appliance or supply) not functioning

definitions: having access to or possession of material goods or wealth to the extent specified

examples.text: we'd been rather badly off for books
how are you off for money?

shortDefinitions: having goods or wealth to extent specified

notes.text: Off of is often used in place of the preposition off in contexts such as she picked it up off of the floor (compared with she picked it up off the floor). Although off of is recorded from the 16th century (it was used by Shakespeare) and is logically parallel to the standard out of, it is regarded as incorrect in standard modern English

definitions: moving away and often down from

examples.text: he rolled off the bed
the coat slipped off his arms
trying to get us off the stage

shortDefinitions: moving away and often down from

definitions: situated or leading in a direction away from (a main route or intersection)

examples.text: single wires leading off the main lines
a backstreet off Olympic Boulevard

definitions: out at sea from (a place on the coast)

examples.text: anchoring off Blue Bay
six miles off Dunkirk

definitions: so as to be removed or separated from

examples.text: threatening to tear it off its hinges
they are knocking $2,000 off the price
it's a huge burden off my shoulders

shortDefinitions: so as to be separated from

definitions: absent from

examples.text: I took a couple of days off work

definitions: abstaining from

examples.text: he managed to stay off alcohol

notes.text: Off of is often used in place of the preposition off in contexts such as she picked it up off of the floor (compared with she picked it up off the floor). Although off of is recorded from the 16th century (it was used by Shakespeare) and is logically parallel to the standard out of, it is regarded as incorrect in standard modern English

definitions: characterized by performing or feeling worse than usual; unsatisfactory or inadequate

examples.text: even the greatest athletes have off days

shortDefinitions: performing or feeling worse than usual

definitions: unwell

examples.text: I felt decidedly off

definitions: (of food) no longer fresh

examples.text: the fish was a bit off

crossReferenceMarkers: Compare with near (sense 4 of the adjective)
definitions: located on the side of a vehicle that is normally furthest from the curb; offside.
shortDefinitions: located on side of vehicle furthest from kerb

definitions: annoying or unfair

examples.text: His boss deducted the money from his pay. That was a bit off

notes.text: Off of is often used in place of the preposition off in contexts such as she picked it up off of the floor (compared with she picked it up off the floor). Although off of is recorded from the 16th century (it was used by Shakespeare) and is logically parallel to the standard out of, it is regarded as incorrect in standard modern English

definitions: the half of the field (as divided lengthways through the pitch) toward which the batsman's feet are pointed when standing to receive the ball.
shortDefinitions: half of field as divided lengthways through pitch toward which batsman's feet are pointed when standing to receive ball

notes.text: Off of is often used in place of the preposition off in contexts such as she picked it up off of the floor (compared with she picked it up off the floor). Although off of is recorded from the 16th century (it was used by Shakespeare) and is logically parallel to the standard out of, it is regarded as incorrect in standard modern English

definitions: kill; murder

examples.text: I finally snapped and offed the guy
